repo.description: The most widely used Python to C compiler
repo.name: cython

comment_data.body:
Don't think this should be `except +`. The exception is caught by Cython immediately and converted into a Python exception.

Similarly with the others.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -39,11 +39,16 @@ cdef inline object {{cname.replace("PyObject", py_type, 1)}}(const string& s):
 
 cdef extern from *:
     cdef cppclass vector "std::vector" [T]:
-        void push_back(T&)
+        ctypedef size_t size_type
+
+        void reserve(size_type) except +
+        void push_back(T&) except +
 
 @cname("{{cname}}")
-cdef vector[X] {{cname}}(object o) except *:
+cdef vector[X] {{cname}}(object o) except +*:

@@ -39,11 +39,16 @@ cdef inline object {{cname.replace("PyObject", py_type, 1)}}(const string& s):
 
 cdef extern from *:
     cdef cppclass vector "std::vector" [T]:
-        void push_back(T&)
+        ctypedef size_t size_type
+
+        void reserve(size_type) except +
+        void push_back(T&) except +
 
 @cname("{{cname}}")
-cdef vector[X] {{cname}}(object o) except *:
+cdef vector[X] {{cname}}(object o) except +*:

@@ -39,11 +39,16 @@ cdef inline object {{cname.replace("PyObject", py_type, 1)}}(const string& s):
 
 cdef extern from *:
     cdef cppclass vector "std::vector" [T]:
-        void push_back(T&)
+        ctypedef size_t size_type
+
+        void reserve(size_type) except +

comment_data.body:
PEP 424, maybe?
https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0424/

You could also check for the `sq_length` slot on the type directly, which is much faster than going through the generic `hasattr()`, especially for the most common types: containers (yes) and generators (no). `ObjectHandling.c` has examples where we use `sq_length()` directly.

Seems worth a separate PR.

edit: Oh, and if you really feel ambitious, you could also start generating one function per input type, set the type on the argument, and let Cython optimise the loop according to the input type.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -39,11 +39,16 @@ cdef inline object {{cname.replace("PyObject", py_type, 1)}}(const string& s):
 
 cdef extern from *:
     cdef cppclass vector "std::vector" [T]:
-        void push_back(T&)
+        ctypedef size_t size_type
+
+        void reserve(size_type) except +
+        void push_back(T&) except +
 
 @cname("{{cname}}")
 cdef vector[X] {{cname}}(object o) except *:
     cdef vector[X] v
+    if hasattr(o, '__len__'):
+        v.reserve(len(o))

comment_data.body: To match the definition in the vector.pxd file. It could be `        void reserve(size_t) except +` instead if that is preferred

comment_data.body: Is there a reason, why I can not directly import the pxd files for these containers here, or did they simply not exist back then and should be used in there as well?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -39,11 +39,16 @@ cdef inline object {{cname.replace("PyObject", py_type, 1)}}(const string& s):
 
 cdef extern from *:
     cdef cppclass vector "std::vector" [T]:
-        void push_back(T&)
+        ctypedef size_t size_type
+
+        void reserve(size_type) except +

comment_data.body: These declarations are small and self-contained, and they avoid a bit of pxd lookup overhead when processing the snippets. Given that users can modify the import path, it seems safer to keep them right in here, in order to avoid potential failures that would be rather difficult to understand for users.

commit.message: Reduce memory allocations in List/Vector conversion
Catch more exceptions from C++ standard containers

repo.description: The most widely used Python to C compiler
repo.name: cython

milestone.description:
Goals:
– New version scheme: 3.x instead of 0.x.
– Change default `language_level` from `2` to `3`.
– Change default for `binding` directive from `False` to `True`.
– Fix some Python compatibility issues (if possible, allowing for breaking changes).

title: Catch more exceptions from C++ standard containers
